title: 111_hr4409
content:
The "Community-Based Residency Training Act of 2009" is cited as the short title. It amends the Public Health Service Act to include training of medical residents in community-based settings. The Secretary will establish a program for training medical residents in community-based settings through grants and contracts. Eligible entities can receive grants to plan and develop new primary care residency training programs or operate existing ones. This includes activities like curriculum development, faculty recruitment, and resident training. The Secretary will establish a program for training medical residents in community-based settings through grants and contracts. Eligible entities must be designated to receive payment for medical education costs under the Social Security Act. Preferences will be given to entities supporting teaching programs for vulnerable populations or those that are Federally qualified health centers or rural health clinics. In awarding grants and contracts, the Secretary will give preference to entities with a proven record of training health professionals in primary care, individuals from disadvantaged backgrounds, and those serving underserved areas or populations experiencing health disparities. The Secretary will award grants and contracts to entities with a track record of training health professionals in primary care, disadvantaged backgrounds, and underserved areas. Grants under subsection (b)(1) have a maximum 3-year period, while grants under subsection (b)(2) have a maximum 5-year period. Renewal is not allowed for grants under subsection (b)(1), and there should be no overlap in periods for grants awarded to the same entity under subsections (b)(1) and (b)(2). The Secretary must submit an annual report to Congress on the program, and definitions are provided in this section. The program under this section focuses on addressing health disparities, which are population-specific differences in disease presence, health outcomes, and access to healthcare. Definitions provided include terms like 'health disparities' and 'primary care resident' as outlined in the Social Security Act. The primary care residency training program is defined as an approved medical residency program for primary care residents, accredited by the Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education or the American Osteopathic Association. Authorization of appropriations includes $40,800,000 for fiscal year 2011 and $43,010,000 for fiscal year 2012. Authorization of appropriations for the primary care residency training program: 
$43,010,000 for fiscal year 2012, $45,050,000 for fiscal year 2013, $47,260,000 for fiscal year 2014, and $49,640,000 for fiscal year 2015.
